title: Sanji's Chivalry as a Character Flaw
theory: Sanji's absolute refusal to fight women, while noble, is portrayed as a genuine character flaw rather than purely virtuous behavior. The Kalifa incident demonstrates that his code can actively endanger his crew and mission, suggesting that rigid adherence to any principle, even a good one, can be problematic when it conflicts with protecting those you care about.
author: One Piece Community
evidence: Sanji is completely unable to fight Kalifa despite Robin's life being at stake
He admits the code was 'beaten into him as a kid,' suggesting trauma rather than choice
The episode frames his defeat as tragic rather than heroic
Nami must step in to cover for his weakness

title: The Straw Hats' Complementary Weaknesses
theory: The Enies Lobby arc deliberately showcases how each Straw Hat has specific limitations that require other crew members to compensate. Sanji cannot fight women, so Nami takes over against Kalifa. This reinforces the theme that the crew needs all its members and their diverse strengths to overcome challenges no single member could handle alone.
author: One Piece Community
evidence: Sanji defeats powerful male opponents but cannot fight Kalifa
Nami struggles against Kumadori but can fight Kalifa effectively
Zoro and Sogeking must work together while handcuffed
The episode emphasizes teamwork over individual strength

title: Kalifa's Devil Fruit as a Counter to Sanji
theory: Kalifa's Awa Awa no Mi and her gender make her the perfect counter to Sanji specifically. Her ability to weaken opponents through touch is devastating against someone who won't fight back, suggesting CP9 or the World Government may have strategically positioned her knowing about Sanji's code of chivalry.
author: One Piece Theorists
evidence: Kalifa's power is particularly effective against non-resisting opponents
CP9 had intelligence on the Straw Hats from their time in Water 7
The matchup seems almost deliberately designed to exploit Sanji's weakness

title: Zeff's Training Created Sanji's Unbreakable Code
theory: Sanji's statement that his chivalry was 'beaten into him' as a child, combined with his absolute inability to violate it even when lives are at stake, suggests this isn't just a moral choice but a deeply ingrained psychological conditioning from Zeff's training. This makes his code almost a form of trauma response rather than a conscious ethical decision.
author: Character Psychology Analysts
evidence: Sanji explicitly says it was 'beaten into him'
He tearfully admits he cannot violate it even to save his life
His physical inability to kick women seems almost pathological
The code appears stronger than his conscious will or rational judgment
